articles.title: Brisbane's time in the sun
articles.author: Jil Hogan
articles.summary: Brisbane's winter weather is inviting, especially in winter. The average maximum temperature is around 22°C, so it's the perfect weather for outdoor activities.       .   for alfresco activities in the winter.

articles.title: B.C. drivers urged to watch for wildlife on roads – the cause of 11,500 crashes per year
articles.author: Andrew Weichel
articles.summary: B.C. enters 'peak' season for deer crossings this month. Road Safety at Work, an injury-reduction initiative of WorkSafeBC, urges drivers to stay alert on the highways. There were 12,825 wildlife crashes across the province in 2023 and 1,070 people were injured.

articles.title: Climate Change Will Cause a Lifetime of Extreme Heat for Today's Children
articles.author: Scientific American
articles.summary: Today's young people will be exposed to heat waves that no one would have experienced before the burning of fossil fuels started raising global temperatures, says Dr. Richard Branken says. He warns that the heat waves will be worse than before the use of Fossil Fuels.

articles.title: If You're Listening: Australia vs The Internet (Part 3) The Trump Effect
articles.summary: Matt Bevan explains the biggest story in world news while hiding in his basement from assassins and authoritarian regimes. The world is on fire. Inflation is through the roof and AI is taking our jobs, so what does it all mean? Matt explains it to ABC News.

articles.title: A commitment to a climate resilient Essex County
articles.author: --Ppa-Color-Scheme
articles.summary: Essex County Community Foundation (ECCF) recently announced a $3 million, 5-year investment in a climate resilient Essex County for all. In Essex County, 74% of cities and towns are at risk from coastal, inland and storm surge flooding. ECCF's climate resiliency work is being supported by an initial grant from the Barr Foundation.

articles.title: Members of WKU's Habitat for Humanity chapter to volunteer in North Carolina
articles.author: Gabrielle Bunton
articles.summary: Six members of Western Kentucky University's Habitat for Humanity Campus Chapter will begin their summer break with a volunteer project in Burnsville, North Carolina. The group will be working on houses with Fuller Center for Affordable Housing - Fuller Center Disaster ReBuilders in Yancey County. The county received the highest three-day total of rainfall during Hurricane Helene in September 2024.

articles.title: U.S. stops tracking costs of extreme weather disasters fueled by climate change
articles.summary: NOAA will no longer update its Billion-Dollar Weather and Climate Disasters database beyond 2024. The database has data going back to 1980 and has tracked hundreds of major events across the country, including destructive hurricanes, hail storms, droughts and freezes that have totaled trillions of dollars in damage.

articles.title: King Dinosaur's Origin: New Evidence Found – Archyde: Latest World News, Economy, Entertainment, Health, Technology & Sports Updates
articles.author: archyde
articles.summary: The ancestors of Tyrannosaurus Rex traversed the Bering land bridge 70 million years ago. The extinction of the Carcharodontosaurids created an ecological opportunity for T. Rex to grow up to 9 tons and dominate the food chain. The research also reveals a correlation between global temperatures and the body size of Tyrannosaurid.

articles.title: 92% of kids born in 2020 could face extreme heatwaves in their lifetime, warns study
articles.summary: Young people will face far more extreme climate events in their lifetimes than previous generations. People living in low-income regions or with high socioeconomic vulnerability will suffer the most. There is an urgent need for stronger climate action and better support for the world's most vulnerable communities.

articles.title: Study shows the world's richest leave biggest carbon footprints and climate damage
articles.summary: The richest 10% of individuals are responsible for two thirds of global warming since 1990. The richest one percent contributed 26 times more to once-a-century heatwaves than the global average. The rich one percent accumulated US$42 trillion in new wealth over the past decade.

articles.title: Low snowpack, early snowmelt, warm weather in forecast point to higher B.C. drought risk, says forecaster
articles.author: Jon Azpiri
articles.summary: B.C.'s snowpack is 71% of normal levels as of May 1, down from 79% on April 1. Snowmelt is happening earlier than usual, with 15% of the peak total snowpack melting by May 1. Environment Canada's seasonal forecasts indicate warmer-than-normal temperatures from May to July. The B.C. Wildfire Service's summer forecast expects higher than usual temperatures into spring, with the possibility of above-average precipitation.

articles.title: World reacts to shock development in Antarctica: ‘Oh my god!'
articles.author: Andrew McMurtry
articles.summary: Antarctic Ice Sheet grew by 108 billion metric tons of ice per year between 2021 and 2023. Between 2002 and 2010, the AIS lost mass at a rate of 74 gigatons a year. The recent increase in ice has seen a 0.30mm offset between 2021-2023. Vincennes Bay and Denham had suffered 'intense' losses.

articles.title: American-born Pope Leo inspires hope in Great Falls
articles.author: Joee Taylor
articles.summary: It will be cloudy with rain after midnight in Griffin, GA. Rainfall will be 100% in the morning. The rain will lessen after midnight. The weather is going to be cloudy and will become light and variable in the rest of the day. The risk of rain is high.

articles.title: The deliberate destruction of Australian quality of life
articles.author: Unconventional Economist
articles.summary: This century has seen a remarkable transformation of Australia. In the 60 years post-World War II, Australia's net overseas migration averaged 90,000 per year. Now, it has more than doubled to 233,000 a year. Australia's population has ballooned by 8.7 million people (46%) since the turn of the century.

articles.title: US Database Tracking Climate Change Losses Goes Offline
articles.author: Newser Editors
articles.summary: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is retiring its database that tracks the cost of losses from climate change-fueled weather disasters. It's the latest example of the Trump administration limiting federal government resources on climate change. The database has tracked hundreds of major events across the country, including destructive hurricanes, hailstorms, droughts, and freezes.

articles.title: Mangrove Restoration Workshop May 14 and 15
articles.author: University
articles.summary: Two public workshops on coral and mangrove restoration will take place on May 14 at Coral World and on May 15 at Island Life Watersports in Bovoni. The workshops are part of the National Science Foundation-funded 'Strong Coasts' project. The initiative seeks to engage local residents in developing nature-based solutions that strengthen climate resilience in coastal communities.

articles.title: Ocean City wind farm project sparks debate on Eastern Shore
articles.author: Jeff Morgan
articles.summary: U.S. Wind plans to construct a wind farm off the coast in Ocean City, Maryland. The proposed wind farm has ignited controversy among locals. Some people support the project, while others are against it. Senator Mary Beth Carozza has been actively opposing the project.

articles.title: It is time to protect India's workers from the heat
articles.author: Aravind Unni
articles.summary: Delhi's temperature soared above 41°C in the first week of April 2025. The Reserve Bank of India has pointed out that extreme heat threatens the health and livelihoods of occupationally exposed people. Many Indian cities now have Heat Action Plans (HAPs), inspired by pioneering efforts as in Ahmedabad. Most HAPs are perfunctory, underfunded and poorly coordinated. In India, informal workers are largely invisible.

articles.title: NOAA to Cease Tracking Financial Costs of Climate Disasters Amid Budget Cuts and Program Shutdowns – [your]NEWS
articles.author: your NEWS Media Newsroom
articles.summary: NOAA will stop collecting and updating data on the financial costs of extreme weather and climate events in the United States. The agency's decades-old disaster cost database will be retired after 2024. The database has documented economic losses from floods, hurricanes, wildfires, and heat waves since 1980. The Trump administration proposed a $1.5 billion cut to NOAA's funding for fiscal year 2026.

articles.title: Flash floods kill two, injure three in eastern Afghanistan
articles.author: Earth Changes
articles.summary: Two people have been killed and three injured in flash floods in Khost province. The floods were triggered by heavy rainfall. The province is already struggling with economic difficulties and limited resources for disaster response. On Sunday, torrential rains and flooding in northern Badakhshan province resulted in two deaths and three injuries. Afghanistan's mountainous terrain and fragile infrastructure make it susceptible to seasonal flooding.

articles.title: Guardian: '… Urgent Theatre … the key to tackling climate change'
articles.author: Eric Worrall
articles.summary: There is a new wave of urgent theatre taking action on climate change. A 12ft-tall puppet of a 10-year-old Syrian girl called Little Amal walked 8,000km from Turkey to the UK to raise awareness of the plight of refugees. This summer a team began a 20,000 km journey, shepherding a group of lifesize animal puppets from the Congo basin to the Arctic Circle.

articles.title: Minister advises development partners to collaborate to mitigate climate impacts
articles.author: Albert Allotey
articles.summary: Issifu Seidu is the Minister of State in charge of Climate Change and Sustainability. He has urged development partners such as civil society organisations to collaborate and advocate for mitigation of climate change impacts on Ghanaians. Northern Patriots in Research and Advocacy (NORPRA) congratulated him on his appointment. NORPRA called on the government to fast-track the establishment of the Renewable Energy Investment and Green Transition (REIGT) Fund and the development of the five-year cycle strategic document for implementation of the Energy Transition Framework.

articles.title: Perth set to break 118-year-old May heat record amid historically warm autumn for NSW, Tasmania and Victoria
articles.author: Alison Osborne
articles.summary: Perth started May with a sunny high of 31.6C, the warmest May temperature since 2018. May days over 30C are rare for Perth, with the average occurrence of 0.4 days over that temperature per year. The last 20 years, only 3 May days with 30C or more occurred in Perth. Monday could also exceed 30C, setting a new record for late season heat.

articles.title: How women bear climate crises they didn't create
articles.author: ENE OSHABA
articles.summary: The climate crisis in Nigeria has a disproportionate impact on women, especially in rural communities. Environmental advocates highlight how women are the most affected yet least included in climate policy decisions. They were speaking at the launch of the Climate Justice Movement (CJM) in Abuja. Ogunlade Olamide Martins, Associate Director of Climate Change at CAPPA, called the launch a turning point.

articles.title: Worst Climate Stories of the Week-Funeral for a Narrative Edition – [your]NEWS
articles.author: Restoration News Staff
articles.summary: This week's Climate Cultists' column focuses on the truth about the global warming agenda. Other stories are weird and good news. Last week's column was about Geoengineering Madness and the Iberian Nightmare. This week it's about the Antarctic Sea Ice and the sudden spike in global temperatures in 2023. In Good News, we have more EV implosions and NOAA retires its boondoggle.

articles.title: WFP warns of deepening hunger in west and Central Africa as millions struggle to feed themselves
articles.author: Modernghana
articles.summary: Millions of people in West and Central Africa are at risk of extreme hunger due to persistent conflict, displacement, economic deterioration, and recurrent extreme weather. WFP urgently needs US$ 710 million to continue life-saving assistance for the most vulnerable in the region for the next six months (May–October 2025).

articles.title: NOAA will no longer track the country's costliest climate disasters
articles.author: Savannah Harriman-Pote
articles.summary: NOAA will no longer update its database of the country's costliest weather and climate disasters. It has been tracking extreme climate and weather events that result in more than $1 billion in damages since the 1980s. Two disasters in Hawai'i have made that list: the Maui fires in 2023 and Hurricane Iniki in 1992.

articles.title: Europe increasingly vulnerable to hailstones the size of golfballs
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: Huge hailstones more than 5 cm in diameter pose a growing threat to Europe as the climate warms. There is an increasing risk of expensive damage to cars and property due to the hailstorm.    -   for more information, go to: http://www.hailstorminfo.org/

articles.title: Live at 1 p.m. ET: A Critique of the Climate Apocalypse with Dr. Judith Curry — The Climate Realism Show #156
articles.author: Charles Rotter
articles.summary: A new paper by Dr. Judith Curry and economist Harry DeAngelo warns investors and the public that the 'apocalyptic climate narrative is a seriously flawed guide for public policy. Heartland's Anthony Watts, Linnea Lueken, H. Sterling Burnett, Jim Lakely, and Dr. Curry will discuss it live on The Climate Realism Show at 1 p.m. ET.

articles.title: Malaysia plays vital role in global bird conservation
articles.summary: This year's theme for World Migratory Bird Day (WMBD) is 'Creating Bird-Friendly Cities & Communities'. It highlights the importance of adapting urban and rural environments to support the survival of migratory birds. WMBD is observed biannually on May 10 and Oct 11.

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'There's a new anti-climate-action playbook in town' By ARIANNA SKIBELL
articles.author: ARIANNA SKIBELL
articles.summary: There's a new anti-climate-action playbook in town. The main talking point is that climate change is a problem, but not as important as other issues, such as malnutrition, access to clean water, air pollution, endemic diseases and human rights. The solution to the world's major ills, according to Chris Wright and his contemporaries, is more energy.

articles.title: U.S. automakers slam Trump's tariff cut on UK vehicles
articles.author: Brett Rowland
articles.summary: It will be cloudy with rain after midnight. Rainfall around a quarter of an inch is possible. High 81F. Winds will be light and variable, with a slight risk of a stray shower or thunderstorm in the afternoon.    Griffin, GA (30223)

articles.title: The Climate Scaremongers: More Lies From The UK's Crackpot Climate Change Committee
articles.author: Paul Homewood
articles.summary: The UK's Climate Change Committee has warned the government that the country is heading for disaster unless it quickly ramps up efforts to tackle 'climate risks'. They say that by 2050, over half of England's prime farmland, one in four homes, and half of roads and rail lines will be at risk of flooding. Heat-related deaths could pass 10,000 in an average year. Unchecked climate change could cost 7 percent of GDP. In reality, the UK climate has not changed a jot in the last 25 years.

articles.title: NOAA to stop tracking costs of most extreme weather disasters
articles.author: NBC Bay Area
articles.summary: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will no longer track the cost of climate change-fueled weather disasters. It is the latest example of changes to the agency and the Trump administration in alignment with evolving priorities, statutory mandates, and staffing changes. It's in line with the agency's priorities.

articles.title: Arewa Consultative Forum warns of severe flood risks in 2025
articles.author: Nana Ismail
articles.summary: The Arewa Consultative Forum (ACF) has issued a strong appeal to governments at all levels and residents in flood-prone areas to act swiftly and decisively in preparing for the looming 2025 seasonal floods. The call follows alarming forecasts from the Nigerian Hydrological Services Agency, which has identified 1,249 communities across 176 local government areas in 30 states, including 16 northern states and the Federal Capital Territory (FCT).

articles.title: Gardeners urged to wet their bird table on Sunday
articles.author: Alex Evans
articles.summary: Gardeners are being urged to wet their bird tables this Sunday as the weather is going to be very hot. Bird food supplier warns that leaving food out for birds when it's very hot can cause dehydration. The main food that garden birds need at this time of year is invertebrates.

articles.title: Climate alarmists' deceptive temperature graphic originates from climate activists' handbook
articles.author: Rhoda
articles.summary: Dr Matthew Wielicki has been investigating where one of the most influential and deceptive temperature graphics used by the climate change cult originated. He traced it to a misleading graphic created by an Australian climate activist group and published in their handbook in 2018. This graphic falsely presents today's warming as unprecedented and alarming by comparing smoothed temperature proxy reconstructions with modern instrumental temperature data. Misuse of climate data is incentivised by organisations like the IPCC, which have vested interests in perpetuating a narrative of crisis.

articles.title: Ensure proper living condition at sea-erosion rehabilitation colony: NHRC to Odisha govt
articles.author: Statesman News Service
articles.summary: The plight of people living in Odisha's first sea-erosion-affected rehabilitation colony in Kendrapara district has come under National Human Rights Commission's scanner. The Commission issued notice and sought for the ATR within four weeks. The 12-kilometer-long stretch beach at Satabhaya Gram Panchayat is stated to be the 'fastest-eroding' beach on the state's long coast. More than 600 homes and large tracts of agricultural land were swallowed by the advancing waters in the last 40 years.

articles.title: Heat Waves Getting Worse? Blame The Super Rich, Says New Climate Study
articles.author: Studyfinds Staff
articles.summary: The richest 10% of people caused two-thirds of global warming since 1990, while the top 1% contributed one-fifth of temperature increases. If everyone emitted like the top 10%, we'd face a catastrophic 2.9°C warming in just 30 years. The top 10% contribute seven times more to extreme heat events than the average person. The rich in the U.S., China and Europe are having huge impacts on climate extremes that hit vulnerable communities worldwide.

articles.title: Senator Ossoff pushes for swift relief for Georgia farmers
articles.summary: Georgia farmers were affected by Hurricane Helene. Senator Jon Ossoff urged Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins to expedite hurricane relief for Georgia farmers affected by the storm. Secretary Rollins promised to make the funds available by the end of the month or in the next week.

articles.title: Green central bankers group publishes first short-term climate scenarios
articles.author: IPE
articles.summary: NGFS scenarios address how climate change-related impacts could unfold in the next five years and how they could be caused by climate change in the current and in the coming years.   Â      i   in the NGSFS scenarios.

articles.title: GCA Welcomes Denmark's Ole Thonke to its Advisory Board
articles.author: Nasdaq Globe Newswire
articles.summary: The Global Center on Adaptation announced the appointment of H.E. Mr Ole as the new director of the GCA today. He will be based in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. He was appointed by GCA's director general, Mr Ole.

articles.title: CHEERS AND JEERS: Cheers to P.E.I. journalists for AJA nominations
articles.author: Guardian Staff
articles.summary: Yutaro Sasaki has been nominated for an Atlantic Journalism Award for his work demonstrating the effects of climate change on Prince Edward Island's primary industries. Thinh Nguyen was nominated for a series on a migrant worker he wrote as a Guardian employee in 2024. P.E.I. curler Brett Gallant and his wife Jocelyn Peterman have earned their way to the Olympics in mixed doubles curling.

articles.title: Environment Canada warning of poor air quality across Manitoba
articles.author: CTV
articles.summary: Environment and Climate Change Canada is concerned about climate change. It's concerned about the effects of climate change on the environment and climate change change on people's lives. Its main focus is on people and their livelihoods. It is also concerned about people's well-being.

articles.title: NOAA to stop tracking costs of extreme weather fueled by climate change
articles.author: Alexa St. John
articles.summary: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will no longer track the cost of climate change-fueled weather disasters. It is the latest example of changes to the agency and the Trump administration limiting federal government resources on climate change. NOAA is tasked with daily weather forecasts, severe storm warnings and climate monitoring. It's also parent to the National Weather Service.

articles.title: 18 beautiful places that we are slowly losing to the sea
articles.author: Ellie Ross
articles.summary: Coastal erosion is eating away at shores all over the world, forcing residents and wildlife to flee and putting lives at risk. Climate change, rising sea levels and worsening storms are accelerating the damage. Before-and-after images show what the world has already lost to coastal erosion.

articles.title: The Graph That Lied
articles.author: Charles Rotter
articles.summary: Tom Nelson is a member of Guerilla Science, a group dedicated to exposing the falsification of climate change claims. He explains the origin of the famous climate change graph, which is based on the same data as NASA, NOAA and the UK Met Office. Tom points out that the population has grown and urbanization has increased, which has affected the location of thermometers.

articles.title: Afghanistan faces food crisis amid 40% rainfall drop and rising heat: Report
articles.author: Fidel Rahmati
articles.summary: Afghanistan is on the brink of a food security crisis due to low rainfall, rising temperatures, and poor crop conditions. More than half of the country's population now requires humanitarian aid. The most severe declines in rainfall have been in the northern and western provinces. In April, temperatures across Afghanistan were 2 to 4 degrees Celsius above normal.

articles.title: Antarctic glacier is rapidly siphoning ice from neighboring flows
articles.author: Pranjal Malewar
articles.summary: Glaciers feeding the Dotson and Crosson Ice Shelves in West Antarctica are among the fastest-changing in the world. Since 2005, glaciers in the Pope-Smith-Kohler region have sped up by 51% on average, though rates vary. The fastest glaciers, Kohler East and Smith West gained an average of 32 meters per year, while Kohler West slowed down by 10%.

articles.title: Migratory birds stop over in the Philippines. Here's how we can protect them.
articles.author: pfkahanap0307
articles.summary: The Philippines is part of the East Asian-Australasian Flyway, which houses about 276 migratory waterbirds. Some natural coastal habitats in the country serve as stopovers for birds on their way to greener pastures. Environmental advocates observe World Migratory Bird Day twice a year to call for the protection of migratory birds and their habitats.

articles.title: Africa: WFP Warns of Deepening Hunger in West and Central Africa As Needs Reach New Highs
articles.author: All Africa
articles.summary: The U.N. World Food Programme (WFPI) is concerned about persistent conflict, displacement, economic deterioration and recurrent extreme weather in the world's poorest countries. WFP is based in Dakar, Senegal, the capital of Dakar.

articles.title: Doctor shares how heatwave worsens your asthma, suggests 6 urgent signs to watch out for
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: People with asthma are at risk during heatwaves. Climate and temperature changes act as triggers that can exacerbate asthma, which is on the rise during the summer months.    .      for people with respiratory issues, because heat relaxes muscles and broadens the airways.

articles.title: Climate change intensified April flooding in Kentucky, according to scientific modeling
articles.author: The Paducah Sun
articles.summary: An increasingly warming climate intensified the deluge of rain that fell on Kentucky and other states in early April, according to a new report from a multinational academic group that studies climate change's connections to extreme weather events. The report was released by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

articles.title: Climate change made April flooding worse, study says
articles.author: Evan Bush
articles.summary: From April 3 to April 6, torrential rain pounded the Southeast, causing flooding that put more than 70 million people under flood alerts, killed at least 15 and swept away cars and derailed a train. The storm system was about 9% more intense because of global warming and 40% likelier today than in a climate without global warming.

articles.title: World`s Richest 10 Per Cent Responsible For Most Global Warming Since 1990, Study Finds
articles.author: Zeenews
articles.summary: The wealthiest 10% are disproportionately driving climate change, according to a new study. This is contributing to extreme heat and droughts around the world.    .   i   in the study.  in this context, the richest 10% of people are disproportionately responsible for climate change.

articles.title: New report raises concerns about price spikes for common food items: 'The price trend is clear'
articles.author: Brianne Nemiroff
articles.summary: Extreme weather has increased the price of staple produce items in the United Kingdom by at least 15%. The most affected items are lettuce, carrots, cucumbers, peppers, cauliflower, zucchini, onions, and broccoli. Tomatoes and mushrooms have also been affected, but those price increases amounted to only 3.88% and 2.30%.

articles.title: Global sea levels are rising faster and faster. It spells catastrophe for coastal towns and cities
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Global sea levels started rising in the 20th century. Scientists are scrambling to understand what this means for the future. It's like we're putting our foot on the gas pedal, says Dr. Richard Brinke.       .

articles.title: Turn your lights out: How you can help millions of birds migrating over Iowa this weekend
articles.author: Kate Kealey
articles.summary: There will be an influx of birds in Iowa as species start to migrate northward for spring. More than 12 million birds crossed Iowa from Wednesday, May 7 to Thursday, May 8, with millions more to fly over the state for the rest of the week. An estimated 26 million birds will be in flight during peak migration.

articles.title: Antarctic Glacier Has Been Spotted Committing 'Ice Piracy' On Its Neighbor
articles.author: Stephen Luntz
articles.summary: A fast-moving Antarctic glacier has been observed stealing ice from a slower-moving neighbour. Glaciologists from the University of Leeds studied the movement of seven glaciers in West Antarctica between 2005 and 2022. They found that the glaciers sped up by an average of 51%, while the glaciers on either side of Kohler West were speeding up.

articles.title: Officials spark uproar with sweeping restrictions on iconic beach access: 'Making life miserable'
articles.author: Simon Sage
articles.summary: Rising sea levels threaten the tourist appeal of a beach in Northern Spain. San Sebastián's La Concha beach has been forced to reduce the number of parasols installed from 440 to 290. The economic costs of sea level rise to coastal cities worldwide over the next century is projected to be in the trillions of dollars.

articles.title: When Will All Life On Earth Die Out? Here's What The Data Says
articles.author: Dr. Katie Spalding
articles.summary: According to some scientists, Earth's biosphere will end in the next 2 billion years due to the combination of overheating and CO2 scarcity for photosynthesis. Alexander Farnsworth and his team found a picture of an Earth virtually uninhabitable by any mammal over the next 250 million years.

articles.title: Climate Change and Illegal Chinese Trawlers Threaten West Africa's Fishing Future
articles.author: Walid Kéfi
articles.summary: Ocean warming and illegal fishing are shrinking fish stocks that millions rely on in West Africa. Small pelagic fish have dropped sharply in Ghana and Côte d'Ivoire since the 1990s. Large industrial fishing vessels, mainly owned by Chinese companies, are worsening the crisis. The report calls for job training and economic alternatives to protect fishing communities.

articles.title: Africa: WFP Warns of Deepening Hunger in West and Central Africa As Needs Reach New Highs
articles.author: wfpinfo@wfp.org
articles.summary: There are persistent conflict, displacement, economic deterioration, and recurrent extreme weather in West and Central Africa. More than 36 million people are struggling to meet their basic food and nutrition needs. WFP urgently needs US$ 710 million to continue life-saving assistance for the most vulnerable in the region for the next six months.

articles.title: Hurricane warnings save lives. National Weather Service cuts may stop them.
articles.author: Tallahassee Democrat
articles.summary: NHC director Michael Brennan talks about the experimental cone of uncertainty and how it is changing for the 2025 hurricane season. The proposed budget for fiscal year 2026 is just $1.5 billion. NHC is preparing for the hurricane season 2025 with new products.

articles.title: Letter: Humanity unable to change climate course
articles.summary: Bob Bretschneider, 79, is a skeptic about global warming. He has been hearing about it since college in the 1970s. He believes that nature is what she wants to do and you can't influence her. The Honolulu Star-Advertiser welcomes all opinions.

articles.title: Global sea levels are rising faster and faster. It spells catastrophe for coastal towns and cities
articles.author: Laura Paddison
articles.summary: Sea level rise was unexpectedly high last year, according to a recent NASA analysis of satellite data. The rate of annual sea level rise has more than doubled over the past 30 years. Melting ice sheets are the biggest uncertainty, as it's not clear how fast they will melt.

articles.title: Record heat in 2023 and 2024 may just have been natural variability
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: Simulations suggest that the jump in temperatures seen in 2023 and 2024 could be natural variability, rather than a new phase of climate change as some researchers have suggested.   Â. Â   y.  y, y, i,

articles.title: Why your next flight could be a lot bumpier
articles.author: Grace Snelling
articles.summary: Professor Paul Williams is a professor of atmospheric science at the University of Reading in England. According to his research, severe clear-air turbulence has increased by 55% since the 1970s and it's only going up. Over the next few decades, turbulence is expected to quadruple along some busy routes, presenting potentially dangerous conditions for aviation.

articles.title: Polk County delays vote on roosters, chicken coops and development issues over pending state bill
articles.author: Paul Nutcher
articles.summary: Polk County Commission will wait for Gov. Ron DeSantis' signature on SB 180 to take away the board's authority to restrict land use. The bill also puts a hold on Polk County proposals to raise the stormwater requirements for developments in stressed basins and expand public-hearing-mailer requirements to property owners within a 1,000 feet of a proposed development.

articles.title: Contributing Factor in 15K US Deaths: Climate Change
articles.author: Arden Dier
articles.summary: Smoke from wildfires worsened by climate change has killed an estimated 15,000 people in the US over 20 years. The annual death toll ranged from 130 to 5,100, with California and Oregon experiencing the highest rates. The study focused on deaths from wildfire smoke between 2006 and 2020.

articles.title: How Climate Change is Altering Bird Migration
articles.author: Deutsche Welle
articles.summary: There are a lot of different ways of looking for a solution to the problem of how to create a solution for the problem. It can be as simple as "bough" or "vig-wich". It can also be more complicated, like "bogus", "bud", "vug-wich", "cushy" and "vog-wich"

articles.title: How climate change is altering bird migration – DW – 05/09/2025
articles.author: Melissa Escaria Parra
articles.summary: Migratory birds cover great distances to feed and breed twice a year. They play a crucial role in keeping nature in balance. They pollinate plants, spread seeds and control pests. They also help to maintain ecosystem health and contribute to food security. Some migratory birds, like Arctic terns, hold the record for the longest migration routes, flying tens of thousands of kilometers to breed. Climate change is making such a feat less likely for some species.

articles.title: The Shifting Rainfall Patterns
articles.summary: Greenhouse gas emissions influence every aspect of Earth's climate, including global wind and precipitation patterns. The Clausius-Clapeyron equation shows that warmer air can hold more water vapor than cooler air. This additional atmospheric water vapor can condense into clouds and eventually precipitate as rain. The Eastern Mediterranean region is situated at the meeting point between a Mediterranean climate zone and a desert climate zone.

articles.title: UNC Biology professor: Greensboro, Winston will have climate of Florida by end of century
articles.author: Chaewon Chung
articles.summary: In recent years, the Triad has seen unusually early warm spells and record-breaking heat waves. The Cape Fear shiner, a small endangered fish that lives only in the Cape Fear River Basin in the Piedmont region, is one of many species struggling to survive as rising temperatures change its environment. Biologists estimate that climate change could drive as much as 35% of plant and animal species to extinction in the wild by 2050.

articles.title: New Climate Report Calls for Urgent Adaptation Strategies in National Plans
articles.author: Business
articles.summary: A report by the NDC Partnership has outlined twelve critical recommendations to strengthen climate adaptation measures in upcoming national climate commitments. 2024 marked the hottest year on record, with global temperatures reaching 1.55 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels. Financing remains a significant hurdle, with annual adaptation funding gaps estimated between 187 and 359 billion dollars globally.

articles.title: Concern for naval bases focused on the wrong enemy
articles.author: Deb Sayer
articles.summary: Chelsea Henderson supports Sen. Angus King's 'grilling' of National Intelligence Director Tulsi Gabbard on the vulnerability of our nation's naval facilities to sea level rise caused by global warming. According to research, land in the entire Hampton Roads region, which includes Norfolk, is sinking at about twice the rate that waters are rising.

articles.title: Climate Activist Draw Attention To Outdated Regulations Of Heli Tourism In Aoraki National Park
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: Climate Liberation Aotearoa recently displayed several large banners around the Aoraki/Mt Cook area to protest for a new long-term sustainability plan for helicopters in Aorakis National Park, to protest against the use of helicopters in the national park.

articles.title: An Inconvenient Antarctic Ice Increase
articles.summary: The ice cap at the South Pole has been growing for three years. Al Gore predicted in 2009 that the north polar ice cap could be completely ice-free within the next five to seven years. Professor Wieslav Maslowski disputed Gore's estimate. Reuters "fact-checked" Gore's 2009 comment.

articles.title: April heat near record levels as global warming accelerates
articles.author: Afp
articles.summary: Global temperatures stuck at near-record highs in April, EU's climate monitor said on Thursday. April was the second-hottest in its dataset, drawing billions of measurements from satellites, ships, aircraft and weather stations. All but one of the last 22 months exceeded 1.5 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels, the warming limit enshrined in the Paris agreement.

articles.title: Nepal at high risk of disasters: Minister Adhikari
articles.author: THT Online
articles.summary: Ramnath Adhikari is speaking at a regional ministerial-level meeting on Integrated Early Warning and Early Action Systems in Colombo on Thursday. The meeting brought together representatives from African and Asian countries to discuss disaster risk, early warning mechanisms and coordinated preparedness efforts.

articles.title: Why experts warn against putting ice on burns
articles.author: TOI Lifestyle Desk
articles.summary: Applying ice to burns can worsen tissue damage due to frostbite and reduced blood flow. Instead, cool minor burns with cool running water for 10-20 minutes, keep the wound clean and moist, and use aloe vera or antibiotic ointment. Seek professional help for severe burns.

articles.title: World Migratory Bird Day 2025: Creating bird-friendly cities and communities
articles.author: Mia Gonzalez
articles.summary: This year's World Migratory Bird Day is on May 10, 2025. The theme is "Shared Spaces: Creating Bird-Friendly Cities and Communities". The 2025 theme focuses on sustainable urban planning, bird-friendly actions, and community efforts to create environments that support both birds and people.

articles.title: Climate Activist Draw Attention To Outdated Regulations Of Heli Tourism In Aoraki National Park
articles.author: Te Pati Maori
articles.summary: Climate Liberation Aotearoa recently displayed several large banners around the Aoraki/Mt Cook area to protest for a new long-term sustainability plan for helicopters in the area. The current plan, last updated in 2004, relies on the concessions system to minimise adverse effects on the natural values of the Park and on other Park visitors.

articles.title: Heat waves are everyone's problem, and the solutions must count everyone too
articles.author: Rahul Tongia
articles.summary: Rising temperatures are a result of climate change, urbanisation and housing design. Most Indians don't have air conditioners or coolers, and some don't even have fans. Modern life is almost 24/7, so we need a societal plan to deal with the heat.

articles.title: Hurricane Recovery
articles.author: STW
articles.summary: Hurricane Recovery is taking place in Chris Hopkins' cotton field near Lyons, Georgia.    pic.twitter.com/xqkqwqvqvjhWJh — Mike Stewart, Mike Stewart’s photo of Chris Hopkins’ cotton field.

articles.title: Your letters on West Norfolk tree protection, beach hut charges, The Walks in King's Lynn and anti-social behaviour in Downham Market
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: Greed has taken over pragmatism concerning beach huts in West Norfolk. The Supreme Court ruling on transgenderism is a victory for common sense. Christians cannot agree with LGBTQ lifestyles, but they do not hate those people or anyone. Downham praises the police for their quick response to the uninvited children at their door.

articles.title: China criticises Australia over joint exercises in South China Sea
articles.author: system
articles.summary: China's Foreign Ministry criticises Australia for joint drills in the South China Sea with the US and the Philippines. It accuses all three nations of trying to "create trouble" in the region.      Â   in Chinese Foreign Ministry.

articles.title: Sindh's mango yield may wither by 50%
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: Climate change and persistent water shortages are threatening to reduce this year's mango harvest by up to 50 per cent in Sindh. Farmers, contractors, and traders are bracing for huge financial losses. The ripening period of the crop may be delayed by 20 to 25 days, affecting the overall supply chain and disrupting export schedules.

articles.title: Earth relies on its magnetic shield for protection
articles.author: Ken Tapping
articles.summary: Earth's magnetic shield protects against harmful effects of the Sun. Mars is an example of what happens when that magnetic field disappears. Evidence of these magnetic field reversals has been found all over the world. There have been at least 183 reversals over the last 83 million years. Some scientists suggest the changes in the Earth's magnetic field are leading to a reversal event.

articles.title: Cold and wet weekend ahead: Weather warnings for Northern and Western Cape
articles.author: Se-Anne Rall
articles.summary: The South African Weather Service has issued several warnings for damaging winds in some parts of the country. Northern Cape and Western Cape are urged to brace for very cold and wet weather this weekend. A Yellow Level 4 warning for damaging waves has been forecast for areas between Table Bay and Plettenberg Bay on Saturday and Sunday.

articles.title: It's almost winter. Why is Australia still so hot?
articles.author: Andrew King
articles.summary: This year, for many Australians, it feels like summer never left. In May, it's still unusually warm. High pressure system has dominated over the south and southeast of Australia over the past few months. The seas around Australia have been warmer than normal, causing coral bleaching to the west and east of the continent.

articles.title: Photos show huge problem facing Australia's fastest growing city: 'Such a high price'
articles.author: Kamilia Palu
articles.summary: As Melbourne's population swells, so does the need for new housing. There are 27 new greenfield sites planned for development over the next decade by the Victorian government. Monash University professor Louise Wright warns the urban sprawl is taking a devastating toll on the environment. Less than one per cent of the Volcanic Plains Grasslands remains in Beveridge to the north as a result of new housing developments. In Sunbury, more estates are encroaching on Aboriginal cultural sites.

articles.title: New Study: 43 Years Of An Increasing Antarctic Sea Ice Trend
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: According to a new study, the recent short-term decreasing Antarctic sea ice concentration (SIC) trend has not offset the overall 43-year trend of increasing Antarctic SIC. The strongly negative sea surface temperatures and SIC correlation coefficient (-0.73) indicates the waters around Antarctica have undergone a long-term cooling trend.

articles.title: Community pulls together to replace American flag lost during Hurricane Helene
articles.author: Ashe Post
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene devastated Ashe County. Homes have been reduced to rubble, roads destroyed and people are left to deal with aftermath of one of the most devastating storms to ever strike the region.      Â   in the wake of Hurricane Helene.

articles.title: Renewable energy must clean up community engagement act or face regulation
articles.summary: Governments and industry are not moving fast enough to prevent regional spotfires being ignited by the march of large-scale renewable infrastructure, as the risks of communities being left behind by the transition worsen, says the UNFCCC. The situation is not getting better.

articles.title: A cacophony of song can be heard at this time of year in qathet
articles.author: Tanya Hill
articles.summary: It's peak migration time for migratory birds in the qathet region. Pierre Geoffray has been birding at the Wildwood Bluffs for 25 years. Tony Greenfield has been a birder for 45 years. Geoffray uses the eBird app to track data and report what types of birds he is seeing and where. He hopes to see 200 species this year.

articles.title: Archeologists Join Geologists In The Quest To Define The Age Of Humans
articles.author: Deborah Barsky
articles.summary: Archeologists are working on a new archeology based on evidence of human activity in the Earth's sedimentary record. The Anthropocene epoch is a new stage in the geological record. Some archeologists consider the Anthropocene as an incremental process, whose genesis can be identified diachronically in Earth's strata as early as tens of thousands of years ago. The AWG concluded that the most suitable time to begin the anthropocene is in the 1950s.

articles.title: Hawke's Bay's climate future revealed - droughts, floods and more hot days
articles.author: Alexa Cook
articles.summary: The first climate change assessment report for Hawke's Bay has been released. It shows an increased risk of ex-tropical cyclones, droughts and flooding. The report was commissioned by the Climate Action Joint Committee. Councils are working on flood resilience projects, including a $176 million multi-year investment.

articles.title: Top Comments: Henry David Thoreau's Observations Provide a Baseline to Study Climate Change
articles.author: gizmo59
articles.summary: There is a discussion on how to name the Basic Person's Bill of Rights. Henry David Thoreau kept a detailed record of the climate along the Sudbury River in Massachusetts from 1850 through 1860. He categorized the seasons into 10 discrete seasons based on the physical conditions.

articles.title: Australia's Unseasonal Heat Lingers into Winter
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: This year, for many Australians, it feels like summer never left. It's still warm in southern Australia. High pressure system has dominated over the south and southeast of Australia over the past few months. The seas around Australia have been warmer than normal, causing coral bleaching and harmful algal blooms.

articles.title: Climate casualties
articles.author: Fact Check Iverify
articles.summary: The climate crisis is taking a deadly toll in Pakistan. Children and the elderly are dying from diseases, displacement and neglect. According to a new Amnesty International report, fewer than 5% of deaths in Pakistan are officially recorded. Most go undocumented during disasters. Health spending must rise from 2.91% of GDP to meet global norms. Healthcare workers must be trained to recognise and manage climate-related illness. Older people must be included in health data systems and protected with a universal pension to reduce economic vulnerability during heatwaves and floods. Children's access to education must be preserved in disaster times. Displacement camps must be tailored to the needs of children and older people.

articles.title: Record heat in 2023 and 2024 may just have been natural variability
articles.author: Michael Le Page
articles.summary: Belgium was one of many counties that saw record temperatures in 2024. The past couple of years have set worryingly high temperature records in Belgium and many other countries. The temperature in Belgium has been very high in the last few years, especially in the north.

articles.title: The Climate Crisis: The Time to Act Is Now
articles.author: Malik Muhammad Ashraf
articles.summary: The IPCC warns that we are likely to breach the critical 1.5°C warming threshold within a decade. Climate change is also a moral crisis. Rich nations subsidise fossil fuels by $7 trillion annually. The United States has effectively closed its doors to international students. UK is considering tighter entry requirements for students from countries it considers high-risk.

articles.title: Weather Insider: The National Climate Assessment
articles.author: Spencer Blum
articles.summary: The National Climate Assessment report is meant to be released every four years. The 5th NCA came out in 2023 and was more than 1800 pages long. In April, President Trump fired 400 volunteer scientists working on the report. It is unclear what will happen with the 6th N CA, which is due in 2027.

articles.title: US to stop tracking disaster costs of climate change
articles.author: Alexa St. John
articles.summary: NOAA will no longer update its Billion-Dollar Weather and Climate Disasters database beyond 2024. The database is going to be archived. NOAA is responsible for weather forecasts, severe storm warnings and climate monitoring. It is also parent to the National Weather Service. For decades, it has tracked hundreds of major events across the country, including destructive hurricanes, hail storms, droughts and freezes.

articles.title: Deadly April rainfall in US South and Midwest was made worse by climate change, scientists say
articles.author: Isabella O'malley
articles.summary: The series of storms unleashed tornadoes, strong winds and extreme rainfall in the central Mississippi Valley region from April 3-6 caused at least 24 deaths. 15 deaths were likely caused by catastrophic floods. Some of the moisture that fueled the storms came from the Gulf of Mexico, where water temperatures were abnormally warm by 1.2°C compared to pre-industrial temperatures.

articles.title: Dangerous clear-air turbulence is worsening due to global warming
articles.author: Inside Climate News
articles.summary: Scientists at the European Geosciences Union conference last week said there is growing evidence that global warming is driving a big increase in dangerous clear-air turbulence. The turbulence is projected to double or treble or quadruple over the next few decades, according to professor Paul Williams of the University of Reading.

articles.title: West Antarctic Glacier Steals Ice From Neighbor
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Scientists have discovered a glacier in Antarctica committing "ice piracy" – stealing ice from its neighbour in a phenomenon previously thought to take hundreds or thousands of years. The dramatic glacial theft has occurred over less than 18 years, challenging scientific understanding of Antarctica's ice dynamics and potential sea level rise contributions.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Makes Sundarbans Population Vulnerable to Migration-Related Exploitation
articles.author: Jigyasa Mishra
articles.summary: Rituri, 23, was promised a job in Delhi for Rs 40,000 per month as a background dancer in TV shows, but she was kept alone in a room for two days and then asked to work at a sweatshop for Rs 12,000 a month. Rituri sent Rs 5,000 back home for a few months, but then returned home. The Sundarbans are the largest mangrove ecosystem in the world. Climate change, rising sea level, and frequent cyclones have been changing the crop production and cropping pattern in the area. The region has faced 8 cyclones in 6 years since 2019.

articles.title: Deadly rainfall in U.S. South, Midwest intensified by climate change, scientists say
articles.author: ISABELLA O'MALLEY
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change intensified deadly rainfall in Arkansas, Kentucky, Tennessee and other states in early April. The series of storms unleashed tornadoes, strong winds and extreme rainfall in the central Mississippi Valley region from April 3-6 and caused at least 24 deaths.

articles.title: India needs a heatwave policy
articles.author: Dr Thamizhachi Thangapandian
articles.summary: As India confronts another punishing summer, the realities of climate change are no longer abstract. The first nationwide heatwave alert of 2025 was issued as early as April 8, and large parts of the country are already experiencing temperatures soaring past historical norms. The UN secretary-general's 'Call to Action on Extreme Heat' warns that heat is now the deadliest of all climate hazards. There's no overarching national heatwave policy offers coordination, funding or technical guidance.

articles.title: Feel the burn: The nature of the heat we face is changing. What should you ...
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: IMD does not factor humidity levels into its heatwave parameters. Humidity levels are rising as part of the urban heat island effect. Extreme heatwave conditions are uncomfortable and dangerous, but at least there's the opportunity for sweat to cool the human body, since humidity isn't high.

articles.title: Deadly April rainfall in US South and Midwest was intensified by climate change
articles.author: The Valley News
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change intensified deadly rainfall in Arkansas, Kentucky, Tennessee and other states in early April, according to a group of scientists. It made those storms more likely to occur, they say.       .   in the United States.

articles.title: Deadly rainfall in U.S. South, Midwest intensified by climate change, scientists say
articles.author: Columbia Missourian
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change intensified deadly rainfall in Kentucky, Tennessee, Arkansas and other states in early April, according to the IPCC report.    .   "Climate change" is to blame for the increase in the number of deaths caused by extreme weather events.

articles.title: Dr Marny Lishman: The silent yet common symptoms that could mean you're suffering burnout
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: A leading psychologist has revealed the little-known clues Aussies may be suffering from severe burnout. Classic signs of burnout include feeling fatigued, emotionally drained, withdrawn and unmotivated. Physical symptoms present in the form of headaches, a change in appetite, stomach.

articles.title: Science lays out framework to assess climate liability of fossil fuel majors
articles.author: Mongabay
articles.summary: Lawsuits on behalf of impacted states, cities and other government entities have increased in number to hold the fossil fuel industry accountable for its contribution to climate change-caused economic damages. "Advances in climate economics over the last 10 years have told us quite a bit about the way that local climate hazards translate into damage for people and places"

articles.title: Global temperatures stuck at near-record highs in April: EU monitor
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Global temperatures are stuck at near-record highs in April. April was the second-hottest in the Copernicus Climate Change Service's dataset. All but one of the last 22 months exceeded 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, the warming limit enshrined in the Paris agreement.

articles.title: नेपाल प्रकोप र विपद्का दृष्टिमा उच्च जोखिममा छ : कृषिमन्त्री अधिकारी
articles.author: रासस
articles.summary: samsung.banner_wrapper, Samsung's ad, is composed of the following elements: calc(100% + 2em), flex, align-items, center, margin-bottom, and text-align-items. It's composed of: calc('100%, calc('1', '2', '3', '4', '5', '6'.

articles.title: Temperatures remain above 1.5°Cthreshold after second hottest April
articles.author: Qatar tribune
articles.summary: Last month was the second hottest April on record. April 2025 was 0.6 degrees Celsius above the 1991-2020 average for the month and 1.51 degrees above pre-industrial levels. It's the 21st month in the last 22 months for which the global average surface air temperature was more than 1.5 degrees Celsius higher than the previous year. The last 12 months from May 2024 to April 2025 were 1.58 degrees Celsius warmer than the pre-Industrial era.

articles.title: How climate change is altering bird migration
articles.author: Deutsche Welle
articles.summary: Migratory birds cover great distances to feed and breed. Rising global temperatures may be affecting their migratory routes, as well as their ability to survive on the move.    iReport.com: Are migratory birds affected by rising global temperatures?

articles.title: Nature Paper Claims to Pin Liability for ‘Climate Damages' on Oil Companies
articles.author: The Daily Sceptic
articles.summary: The drumbeat of climate litigation has grown louder in recent years fuelled by activists and dubious science. "Attribution science" has been a fast-growing field of climate research which is explicitly meant to serve legal ends. According to the World Weather Attribution, event attribution was originally suggested with the courts in mind.

articles.title: Antarctic Glacier Has Been Spotted Committing 'Ice Piracy' On Its Neighbor
articles.author: IFL Science
articles.summary: Kohler East glacier is stealing ice from Kohler West. Glaciologists thought it took centuries or millennia to do this, but it took just 18 years. The event is likely a result of global warming.    - because Kohler East's ice stream is flowing and thinning faster as it travels, it absorbs or 'steals' ice from the neighbor.

articles.title: Climate change intensified April flooding in KY, according to scientific modeling
articles.author: Lexington Herald-Leader
articles.summary: A warming climate is to blame for the deluge of rain and flooding that hit Kentucky in early April, according to climate scientists.      Â   in the United States, a warm climate is responsible for the flooding that happened in Kentucky.

articles.title: 12 Actionable Ways to Boost Adaptation in NDCs 3.0
articles.author: Business Ghana
articles.summary: The escalating impacts of climate change highlight a growing shortfall in adaptation efforts. The first Global Stocktake (GST) released in late 2024 notes the 'urgent need for strengthened adaptation action at scale' and calls for transformational and effective adaptation efforts going forward.

articles.title: Trump Administration Decommissions Sea Ice Data That Sounded an Alarm on Arctic Climate Change
articles.author: Scheerpost
articles.summary: Key datasets used to monitor the impacts of climate change in the Arctic will be reduced to Basic due to cost-cutting at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The level of services for affected products will remain accessible but may not be actively maintained, updated, or fully supported.

articles.title: April heat near record levels as global warming accelerates
articles.author: Daily Sabah
articles.summary: Global temperatures stuck at near-record highs in April, EU's climate monitor said on Thursday. It extends an unprecedented heat streak and raises questions about the impact of climate change on the Earth's climate.       in the EU's Climate Monitor.

articles.title: 'Bird Sit' on May 17
articles.author: Weekly Villager
articles.summary: World Migratory Bird Day is on Saturday, May 17th. Meet at the covered bridge along The Rookery's to record the birds seen and heard for a period of time to mark the occasion.       for a bird sit.

articles.title: Afghanistan faces food crisis amid 40% rainfall drop and rising heat: Report
articles.author: Khaama Press
articles.summary: Afghanistan is on the brink of a food security crisis due to low rainfall, rising temperatures, and poor crop conditions, according to a recent report from a U.S.-based agency.       "Famine Early Warning Network"

articles.title: Column: Corporate America owes the rest of us $87 trillion
articles.author: Daily Press
articles.summary: Most climate-change deniers don't even bother fighting the established science anymore. Modern deniers will fire back that the "do something about it" part is too hard, too expensive to be worth trying, and they don't want to do anything at all.

articles.title: NOAA to stop tracking costs of extreme weather fueled by climate change
articles.author: Fast Company
articles.summary: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will no longer track the cost of climate change-fueled weather disasters. It is the latest example of changes to the agency and the Trump administration limiting federal resources on climate change. It's in alignment with evolving priorities, statutory mandates and staffing changes.

articles.title: It's Almost Winter. Why Is Australia Still So Hot?
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: This year, for many Australians, it feels like summer never left. The sunny days and warm nights have continued well into autumn. Even now, in May, it's still unusually warm and sunny, which is unusual for this time of the year in Australia.

articles.title: The Hindu Huddle 2025: ‘Multilateral regime remains relevant in fight against climate change'
articles.author: The Hindu
articles.summary: The planet is warming because of human activities, and it is warming much faster than our models have anticipated, says an expert at The Hindu Huddle. The expert claims that the climate is changing faster than expected.       .   in this article.

articles.title: WMBD calls for creation of bird-friendly cities
articles.author: The Manila Times
articles.summary: 49% of all bird species are in decline and 1 in 8 species is threatened with extinction. Migratory bird populations continue to decrease. Most bird species cannot thrive in human-dominated environments. Global study published in Global is titled "Shared Spaces: Creating Bird-Friendly Cities and Communities".

articles.title: Stronger Solar Activity Cycles May Be in the Sun's Forecast
articles.author: Scientific American
articles.summary: The sun has produced stunning auroras on Earth in recent years as solar activity has peaked. Expect more auroras in the coming years as the sun's activity has declined again.    .   in future years expect more aurora on Earth from the sun.

articles.title: The Carbon Aristocracy: How the Rich Engineered the Climate Crisis — And Made You Pay for It
articles.author: John Mac Ghlionn
articles.summary: The richest 10 percent of the planet caused two-thirds of global warming since 1990. Everyone else got scorched. People who did the least to cause the crisis are the first to lose their homes, jobs, and access to affordable insurance. The rich are protected by complex financial structures, corporate shields, and international loopholes.
